inference:
By the triangle inequality, the sum of the lengths of any two sides of a triangle must be greater than the length of the third side.
$2n+12 + 2n+7 > 3n-3$
$4n+19 > 3n-3$
$n > -22$
$2n+12 + 3n-3 > 2n+7$
$5n+9 > 2n+7$
$3n > -2$
$n > -\frac{2}{3}$
$2n+7 + 3n-3 > 2n+12$
$5n+4 > 2n+12$
$3n > 8$
$n > \frac{8}{3} = 2\frac{2}{3}$

Since $n$ is a positive integer, we have $n > 2\frac{2}{3}$. The smallest integer that satisfies this is $n=3$.  
$\angle A = 3n - 3$
$\angle B = 2n + 7$
$\angle C = 2n + 12$
From the triangle inequality, $\angle A > \angle B > \angle C$.
$\angle A + \angle B + \angle C = 180$
$3n - 3 + 2n + 7 + 2n + 12 = 180$
$7n + 16 = 180$
$7n = 164$
$n = \frac{164}{7} \approx 23.428$
The largest possible value for $\angle C$ is $\angle B - 1$, and the smallest possible value for $\angle A$ is $\angle B + 1$.  Since $2n+12$ is the smallest angle, $2n+12 < 2n+7$, which is impossible.
Thus $\angle A > \angle B > \angle C$, we need
$\angle A > \angle B \implies 3n-3 > 2n+7 \implies n > 10$
$\angle B > \angle C \implies 2n+7 > 2n+12$ which is false.

We have $n > \frac{8}{3} = 2\frac{2}{3}$, which means $n \ge 3$. 
$3n-3 > 2n+7 \implies n > 10$
$2n+7 > 2n+12$ impossible
Thus $n > 10$. Since $7n + 16 = 180$, $7n = 164$, which implies $n = 23.43$.  
Since $n$ must be an integer, $3n - 3 > 2n + 7$, $n > 10$.
$2n+7 > 2n+12$, impossible.
We must have $3n - 3 > 2n+7 > 2n+12$.
We have $3n - 3 > 2n + 7 \implies n > 10$.
Also $2n+7 > 2n+12$ impossible.
$2n+7 + 2n+12 = 4n+19 < 3n-3+2n+7 \implies n<19$
So $10 < n \le 23$ and $n = 11, 12, \dots, 23$.
There are $23-11+1=13$ possible values.

Final Answer: $\boxed{13}$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
The sides of the triangle must satisfy the triangle inequality, so $AB + AC > BC$, $AB + BC > AC$, and $AC + BC > AB$.  Substituting the side lengths, these inequalities turn into \begin{align*}
(3n - 3) + (2n + 7) &> 2n + 12, \\
(3n - 3) + (2n + 12) &> 2n + 7, \\
(2n + 7) + (2n + 12) &> 3n - 3,
\end{align*} which give us $n > 8/3$, $n > -2/3$, and $n > -22$, respectively.

However, we also want $\angle A > \angle B > \angle C$, which means that $BC > AC$ and $AC > AB$.  These inequalities turn into $2n + 12 > 2n + 7$ (which is always satisfied), and $2n + 7 > 3n - 3$, which gives us $n < 10$.

Hence, $n$ must satisfy $n > 8/3$ and $n < 10$, which means \[3 \le n \le 9.\] The number of positive integers in this interval is $9 - 3 + 1 = \boxed{7}$.

ground_truth:
The sides of the triangle must satisfy the triangle inequality, so $AB + AC > BC$, $AB + BC > AC$, and $AC + BC > AB$.  Substituting the side lengths, these inequalities turn into \begin{align*}
(3n - 3) + (2n + 7) &> 2n + 12, \\
(3n - 3) + (2n + 12) &> 2n + 7, \\
(2n + 7) + (2n + 12) &> 3n - 3,
\end{align*} which give us $n > 8/3$, $n > -2/3$, and $n > -22$, respectively.

However, we also want $\angle A > \angle B > \angle C$, which means that $BC > AC$ and $AC > AB$.  These inequalities turn into $2n + 12 > 2n + 7$ (which is always satisfied), and $2n + 7 > 3n - 3$, which gives us $n < 10$.

Hence, $n$ must satisfy $n > 8/3$ and $n < 10$, which means \[3 \le n \le 9.\] The number of positive integers in this interval is $9 - 3 + 1 = \boxed{7}$.
